page.title: 09PENARTH LIFEBOAT STATION.
page.content: The first lifeboat station was opened in 1861. The present station has a "D" class inflatable lifeboat, with a 40 hp. outboard engine, and has a max. speed of 21 knots. It would cost about Â£8,000 to replace. There are 21 men in the crew, but only 3 people are needed to man the boat, and two to help launch it. The crew is led by Capt. W. Sommerfield. Since the present station opened in 1980, the lifeboat has been launched 113 times, and 39 people have been rescued. The most common cause for a callout is to rescue people stranded on Sully Island. Visitors are not aware of the wide tide range, which is the second largest in the world. The crew are all volunteers, and are responsible for the area of coast from Newport to Barry.
